column3: Verify that the website opens successfully without any issues
column5: User has stable internet connection and valid URL
column6: Website link - https://test1.gotrade.goquant.io
column7:
1. Open a web browser
2. Enter the website URL in the address bar
3. Press Enter
column8: The website should load completely without any delay or error messages
column9: Website loaded successfully
column13: The website returned HTTP status code 200 (OK), confirming successful server connectivity.
column14: Website launched successfully and displayed all components correctly.

column3: Verify login functionality using both valid and invalid credentials
column5: User must be on the login page
column6:
Valid:
• Email: user10@goquant.io
• Password: 60Re3G9KvvFl4Ihegxpi Invalid:
• Email: user10@goquant.io
• Password: Invalid123@
column7:
1. Launch the website
2. Navigate to the Login page
3. Enter invalid credentials and click Login
4. Observe the message
5. Clear the fields
6. Enter valid credentials and click Login
7. Observe the result
column8:
Invalid credentials → Error message should be displayed: “Invalid email or password”
Valid credentials → User should be redirected to the Dashboard or Home page
column9:
Invalid credentials: Error message displayed correctly
Valid credentials: User logged in successfully
column13: Network request /auth/login returns HTTP 200 for valid credentials and HTTP 401 (Unauthorized) for invalid ones. No console errors observed. Response payload includes JWT token and user details upon success.
column14: Login flow functions as expected for both valid and invalid credentials. Input field validation and error handling are properly implemented.

column3: Verify that when valid login cookies are saved, reopening the website skips both the login page and the start tour popup
column5:
1. User has successfully logged in previously
2. Valid session cookies and localStorage tokens are present
3. User has already completed or skiped the start tour once
column6:
Valid:
• Email: user10@goquant.io
• Password: 60Re3G9KvvFl4Ihegxpi
column7:
1. Login with valid credentials
2. Verify dashboard loads successfully
3. Skip or complete the start tour
4. Close the browser or tab (without logging out)
5. Reopen the website in the same browser session
column8:
Website should detect saved session cookies and:
• Bypass the login page
• Skip the start tour popup and load the main dashboard directly
column9: Login page and start tour both skipped; dashboard opened directly
column13: Browser retained valid authentication cookies and localStorage tokens (accessToken, refreshToken). On relaunch, initial /auth/session API returned HTTP 200, confirming session validity. No console errors observed.
column14: Session persistence works as expected. System correctly bypasses login and onboarding flow when valid session tokens exist.

column3: Verify that user is able to sign out successfully
column5: User logged in successfully
column6: Valid user session active
column7:
1. Navigate to the user profile 
2. Click Sign Out button
3. Observe if redirected to login page
4. Try re-accessing the app URL to ensure session is cleared
column8: User should be logged out successfully, redirected to login page, and session should be cleared
column9: User successfully signed out; redirected to login page and session cleared
column13: The sign-out API returned status code 200 (OK), confirming that the session token was invalidated and cleared successfully.
column14: Sign-out functionality verified and working as expected

column3: Add multiple exchange accounts with API credentials)
column5: User is logged in and on “Admin” page; valid API credentials available
column6:
OKX: API Key + Secret
Binance USDM: API Key + Secret
Binance CoinM: API Key + Secret
column7:
1. Click “Add Exchange”
2. Select OKX, enter API key & secret, click Save
3. Select Binance USDM, enter API key & secret, click Save
4. Select Binance CoinM, enter API key & secret, click Save
5. Verify all exchanges appear in connected list
column8: All three exchanges added successfully; each shows “Connected”; no error messages
column9: Unable to add accounts; previously connected exchanges show “Cannot communicate with exchange”
column13: Network calls to /api/exchange/connect/* returned 400 error; console shows connection errors
column14: Likely backend/API issue; devs need to check connectivity or API key validity

column3: Verify user is able to modify an existing exchange account
column5: User logged in; at least one exchange account added and visible
column6: Exchange Name: OKX / Binance USDM / Binance CoinM
column7:
1. Navigate to Accounts → Admin
2. Select an existing connected account
3. Click Modify
4. Update API Key or Secret Key
5. Save the changes
column8: Account details should be updated successfully, and confirmation message should appear
column9: Unable to modify the account; an unclear / non-understandable error popup appears, and changes are not saved
column13: API returned HTTP 400 (Bad Request) – "delete_credentials() takes from 1 to 2 positional arguments but 3 were given", indicating a backend function parameter mismatch.
column14: API-side bug identified. The backend method for deleting credentials is receiving extra arguments. Needs developer fix to handle request parameters properly.

column3: Delete previously added exchange accounts
column5: User logged in; at least one exchange account added and visible
column6: Exchange Name: OKX / Binance USDM / Binance CoinM
column7:
1. Navigate to “Admin” list
2. Select an exchange (e.g., OKX)
3. Click “Delete” button
4. Confirm deletion
5. Repeat for other exchanges if needed
6. Verify exchange is removed from the list
column8: Selected exchange(s) should be successfully deleted and removed
column9: Able to delete exchanges
column13: API call DELETE /api/exchange/{id} returned HTTP 200 (OK) confirming successful removal. No backend or console errors observed during operation.
column14: Functionality working as expected. Deletion confirmed at both UI and API levels.

column9: Trades executed successfully for all symbols

column3: Verify OKX trades are displayed correctly in Order History

column6:

3. Place one or more trades (any type) on different symbols
4. Navigate to Order History
5. Check if all OKX trades are visible
column8: All OKX trades should be displayed in Order History with correct symbol, trade type, quantity, and status
column9: OKX trades are inconsistently displayed in Order History
column13: The Order History API intermittently failed to return complete trade data for OKX; some responses lacked symbol or status fields, causing inconsistent display.
column14: Trades placed successfully but not reflected consistently in Order History. Backend response needs validation to ensure all OKX trades are captured and displayed.

column3: Verify that user can cancel an “In Progress” order from the Waiting Orders section
column5: User logged in; at least one trade in “In Progress” state under Waiting Orders
column7:
1. Navigate to GoTrade → Waiting Orders
2. Identify an order with status In Progress
3. Click Cancel on that order
4. Verify that the order status updates accordingly
column8: The selected In Progress order should be cancelled successfully, and its status should change to “Cancelled” or be removed from the list
column9: Popup appeared showing “Order Cancelled”, but the order status in the list remained In Progress.
column13: Cancel API returned a response with status: "timeout" and message "No response received from UDP server". No HTTP 400 or console errors observed. Indicates backend timeout or network latency in UDP order cancel service.
column14: The cancel action triggers a popup but backend response times out, preventing UI status update. Likely UDP communication delay or missing retry logic.

column3: Verify quantity updates correctly when Add/Clear percentage is adjusted in Assets
column5: User logged in; Assets page loaded with available balance
column6: Asset: BTC / ETH / USDT etc.
column7:
1. Navigate to Assets
2. Click Add/Clear button
3. Adjust percentage slider or select predefined percentages (e.g., 25%, 50%, 100%)
4. Observe the Quantity field value
column8: Quantity should update dynamically based on selected percentage of available balance
column9: Quantity value updates correctly as per selected percentage
column13: No console or network errors observed during manual execution. Dropdown responsiveness is slightly delayed on some attempts — likely a UI rendering or debounce issue.
column14: Functionality works correctly in manual testing. However, automation validation is partially limited — dropdown occasionally fails to open on first click, and system-generated input values in the Quantity field cannot be extracted via script for verification. Suggest improving dropdown interaction stability and exposing Quantity value as a readable DOM property for automated tests.

column3: Verify Order Book data is displayed correctly for selected symbol on OKX exchange
column5: User logged in; OKX exchange added and connected
column6: Symbols: BTC, ETH, SOL, etc
column7:
1. Navigate to GoTrade page
2. Switch to OKX exchange
3. Select any symbol (e.g., BTC)
4. Observe the Order Book section
column8: Order Book should display real-time buy/sell data for the selected symbol from OKX
column9: Order Book data not displayed for certain symbols; inconsistent data load observed
column13: WebSocket connection to OKX Order Book stream intermittently fails — some responses show empty payloads or delayed updates. No HTTP/API errors observed in network logs. Indicates unstable or dropped real-time data feed.
column14: Order Book fails to update consistently for specific symbols (e.g., ETH, SOL). Likely issue with WebSocket subscription or data parsing logic.

column14: Real-time data for certain Binance USD-M symbols (e.g., SOL, XRP) not populating in Order Book. Likely caused by unstable WebSocket subscription or missing data relay from backend.

column3: Verify that the Reconciliation page in GoOps displays the correct Order History for the logged-in user
column5: User logged in; trades executed on connected exchanges
column6: Valid trade history (OKX, Binance USDM, Binance CoinM)
column7:
1. Navigate to GoOps module
2. Open the Reconciliation page
3. Observe the list of displayed order histories
4. Cross-check with user’s actual executed orders
column8: The Reconciliation page should display only the logged-in user’s order history with correct symbol, type, quantity, and status
column9: Reconciliation page displays other users’ order history instead of current user’s records
column13: The reconciliation API returned order entries belonging to multiple user IDs; responses contain records not filtered by the current user. No frontend console errors observed—issue appears to be server-side (missing/incorrect user filter or query parameter).
column14: Logged-in user’s order history not isolated; data exposure issue observed

column3: Verify that Shortcut Categories in Settings respond correctly to valid and invalid key combinations
column5: User logged in; Shortcut Categories configured
column6:
Example:                                           Valid key: Alt + P
Invalid key: Shift + P
column7:
1. Navigate to Settings → Shortcut Categories
2. Press Alt + P and observe behavior
3. Press Shift + P and observe behavio
column8: Only valid shortcut (Alt + P) should redirect to GoOps page; invalid shortcuts should have no action

column14: Shortcut validation missing; frontend should filter invalid key combinations
